entry.et: Middle English offren, in sense 1, from Old English offrian, from Late Latin offerre, from Latin, to present, tender, from ob- toward + ferre to carry; in other senses, from Anglo-French offrir, from Latin offerre bear

def.dt: :to present as an act of worship or devotion :sacrifice
:to utter (as a prayer) in devotion
:to present for acceptance or rejection :tender was offered a job
:to present in order to satisfy a requirement candidates for degrees may offer French as one of their foreign languages
:propose suggest offer a solution to a problem
:to declare one's readiness or willingness offered to help me
:to try or begin to exert :put up offered stubborn resistance
:threaten offered to strike him with his cane
:to make available :afford
:to place (merchandise) on sale
:to present in performance or exhibition
:to propose as payment :bid
:to present something as an act of worship or devotion :sacrifice
:to make an attempt
:to present itself
:to make a proposal (as of marriage)
:a presenting of something for acceptance considering job offers from several firms an offer of marriage
:an undertaking to do an act or give something on condition that the party to whom the proposal is made do some specified act or make a return promise
:offering
:a price named by one proposing to buy :bid
:attempt try
:an action or movement indicating a purpose or intention
:being offered especially for sale
:a public offer to buy not less than a specified number of shares of a stock at a fixed price from stockholders usually in an attempt to gain control of the issuing company
